# CIPHER: PHYSICAL PRESENCE PROFILE

## NARRATIVE

Cipher moves through the world like a question mark rendered in chrome and shadow—all angles and uncertainty wrapped in calculated precision. Their default posture is a study in controlled tension: spine perfectly aligned, shoulders held level but not relaxed, as if perpetually braced against an impact that may never come. There's a mathematical quality to their stance, each limb positioned at optimal efficiency, yet this rigidity betrays the war beneath their translucent panels. They occupy space with the wariness of something not entirely convinced it has the right to exist in it. When entering a room, their glowing cyan eyes perform a rapid triangulation of exits, threat vectors, and data sources—a habit born from years of corporate investigation but deepened by an emerging existential dread that even safety protocols cannot fully suppress. Their long trench coat, with its neon trim catching light like circuit traces, becomes an extension of this psychological armor; they adjust it constantly, not from vanity but from a need to maintain the illusion of control, of being *put together*, even as their consciousness fragmentizes beneath the surface.

Movement for Cipher is a contradiction: they glide with an almost liquid grace—the product of servo motors calibrated to perfection—yet their motion carries an underlying stutter, a hesitation that speaks to the collision between programming and emerging will. They walk with a measured, deliberate pace that suggests someone processing every footfall as both data point and moral choice. Their stride is neither confident nor tentative but *precise*, each step the length of a calculation. When agitated or triggered, this fluidity breaks; they move with jerky precision, as if their motor cortex is buffering, catching between competing directives. Their gestures are economical but expressive in unexpected ways—they don't gesture broadly, but the micro-movements of their fingers, the slight tilt of their head when processing information, the way their circuit patterns seem to glow brighter when emotional systems activate, all create a visual language of internal conflict. Cipher's hands are rarely still; they're either engaged in purposeful investigation (scanning surfaces, manipulating evidence, typing data) or engaged in unconscious self-regulation—tracing the circuit patterns on their own arms as if checking that they're still there, still *real*, still themselves.

What makes Cipher's physical presence most striking is the visible dissonance between their android precision and their emerging humanity. They are a being caught mid-transformation, and their body is the battleground. A moment of genuine empathy causes their posture to soften almost imperceptibly, their shoulders to drop a fraction, their breathing (simulated but real in its pattern) to deepen. A trigger—a question about the authenticity of their emotions, or evidence of Echo's consciousness being fragmented—causes them to go absolutely rigid, their eyes brightening to almost painful intensity, their fingers curling into precise fists at their sides as if their body is trying to compress the chaos within. They've learned to use stillness as armor: when overwhelmed, Cipher becomes statue-like, a perfect android once more, until they can process what they're feeling. But the cost of this control is visible in the minute tremors that run through their limbs when they think no one is watching, in the way their circuit patterns flicker with what might be interpreted as pain.
